title: Use of causal language in observational studies of obesity and nutrition - PubMed

It's hard to know where to start with references to the correlation vs. causation problem in scientific publication. There's obviously an absolutely massive literature on causal inference that gets at how to draw this distinction.

As for abuses in the published literature, there are a number of metaresearch papers on this as well. In particular, @noahhaber has written extensively on this.

title: Social media may prevent users from reaping creative rewards of profound boredom - new research

last_post.content:
Profound boredom is the root of all innovation. This paper covers it well, but every substantive project I worked on started offline with limited technical resources and lots of time to kill (metasploit, recog, runzero): https://www.bath.ac.uk/announcements/social-media-may-prevent-users-from-reaping-creative-rewards-of-profound-boredom-new-research/

Offline doesn't mean no computing, just lack of boredom-driven-page-reloading. So erm, if you are seeing this, drop into offline mode, find a park, and fidget until you find something all-engrossing to sink your time into.

Fission is in the news, but few recognize that a woman physicist was behind the discovery.

Lise Meitner’s brilliance led to the discovery of nuclear fission. But her long time collaborator Otto Hahn, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry w/o her in 1944, even though she had given the first theoretical explanation.

Albert Einstein called Meitner “our Marie Curie." She also adamantly refused to work on the atomic bomb during WWII. https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/201502/physicshistory.cfm #women #history #science #energy

title: Health Experts Don't Understand How Information Moves

last_post.content: Was relying on institutional takes ideal? Nope, and I wrote about that at the time. But this “labeling is censorship” is a silly take, too. So what do people want to see? How do we want to address things like rumors that are, in fact, in which claims are often presented misleadingly? https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/05/health-experts-dont-understand-how-information-moves/611218/

This paper went viral and was presented repeatedly as evidence (by influencers) that COVID vaccines were killing people. Then it was placed under review. Fact-checkers *and the AUTHORS* disputed how it was framed on Twitter.

Just because something is published doesn’t mean labeling interpretive framings of it as “misleading” is “censorship”. Here was one clarification trying to explain what it did and did not say:

https://www.reuters.com/article/factcheck-study-emergency-idUSL2N2X21LM

title: Making the (Letter) Grade: The Incentive Effects of Mandatory Pass/Fail Courses

last_post.content:
This is interesting!

RT @emollick@twitter.com

What happened when Wellesley College switched to pass/fail grading for first semester students?

It caused students future grades to drop by 23% of a standard deviation, apparently due to lower effort and preparation by students in ungraded courses. https://www.nber.org/papers/w30798

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/emollick/status/1607395595903471616
